AND

Accept any valid alternate argument.

…or M1 for their ‘6.5’ × 10

If 0, 1 or 2 scored, instead award SC3 for answer 255 with no working or insufficient working.  

If 0 or 1 scored, instead award SC2 for 195 or 60 with no working or insufficient working.  

If 0 scored, instead award SC1 for 19.5 or 65 with no working or insufficient working.  

“Correct working” requires evidence of at least M2 and M1.

11.text:
11 (a)  
• 1 mark (1 AO2.5a)  
• Explanation, for example:  
  – “There should be 4 decimal places in the answer.”  
  – “The answer should be smaller than 0.38 (or 0.26).”  
  – “Because 0.4 × 0.3 = 0.12.”  
• Clear sensible reason required (not just giving the actual answer with no working or explanation).  
• Condone: “Multiplying two decimals means a smaller number,” or equivalent.  

(b)  
• 1 mark (1 AO2.5a)  
• Explanation, for example:  
  – “The answer should be bigger than 1 because both 3/4 and 2/3 are bigger than 1/2.”  
  – “The answer should be bigger than 3/4, but 5/7 is smaller than 3/4.”  
• Exemplars for 1 mark:  
  – “You don’t add fractions by adding tops and bottoms.”  
  – “You don’t add the denominators.”  
  – “You have to find a common denominator first.”  
  – “3/4 + 2/3 is obviously > 1.”

16.text:
16. Correct answer (264) with complete correct working, for example:  
(3 + 1) × 6 × 11  

Marks available: 4  
(1 AO1.3a, 3 AO3.1a)  

• M3 for correct working but no final answer stated [(3 + 1) × 6 × 11] or the working is poorly communicated but is clear (for example, (3 + 1) × 6 × 11 = 264), or a number greater than 200 with complete correct working.  

• Or M2 for 264 with no (or incomplete) working, or for an acceptable number over 200 with poorly communicated working.  

• Or M1 for a number greater than 200 with no, or incomplete, working, or for (3 × 6) × 11 [× 1] (condoning any minor calculation error), or for two trials leading to numbers below 200 (condone poor communication), or any acceptable calculation where their result is at least 200 but there is an error in evaluation.  

Working correctly communicated in stages is acceptable for 4 marks. For example:  
3 + 1 = 4  
4 × 6 = 24  
24 × 11 = 264  

A full written explanation is also acceptable.  

For 1 or 2 marks, “acceptable” implies a number (minimum 200) that can be made.
